document:
CEN 3078 Computer Security
Module 1 – Application and Network Analysis

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 4.pptx

document:
Module 1 Overview
Network and application layers – security concepts
Packet sniffing and spoofing
Intrusion detection systems
Legal and ethical issues

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 4.pptx

document:
Cyber Crime and Forensic Evidence
Cybercrime – criminal activity where computers or networks are a tool, target, or location of the crime.
Forensic Evidence – anything used in court to prove a statement’s validity.
Cannot be hearsay – must come from reliable monitoring.
Routine monitoring supports custody and recordkeeping.
Evidence must prove beyond reasonable doubt.

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 4.pptx

document:
Types of Cyber Crime (U.S. DOJ Categories)
• Minimum human supervision
• Recover from crashes and reinitializations
• Self-monitor and detect intruder modification
• Intellectual Property Infringement

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 4.pptx

document:
Intellectual Property
Any intangible asset of human knowledge and ideas.
Examples: software, data, designs, books, inventions.
Protected through:
• Copyrights
• Trademarks
• Patents

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 4.pptx

document:
Copyright
Protects tangible or fixed expression of an idea, not the idea itself.
To claim copyright:
• Work must be original.
• Idea must be expressed in a fixed medium.
Filed through national copyright offices.

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 4.pptx

document:
Patent
Grants a property right to the inventor.
Right to exclude others from making, using, or selling the invention.
Example: RSA public-key cryptosystem (patented 1983–2000).
Types: utility, design, and plant patents.

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 4.pptx

document:
Trademark
A word, name, symbol, or device used in trade.
Indicates source and distinguishes goods or services.
Rights prevent confusingly similar marks but not competition with distinct marks.

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 4.pptx

document:
Privacy
Overlaps with computer security.
Driven by data collection, IoT, social networks, and research.
Concerns over personal data misuse lead to privacy laws and technical protections.
Assures individual control over personal data collection, access, and disclosure.

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 4.pptx

document:
Privacy Protection
Requires both policy and technical measures.
Technical examples:
• Database security controls
• Social media privacy settings
• Tagging notifications
• Data anonymization before release

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 4.pptx

document:
Data Privacy
Policy considerations for managing and reusing data:
• Consent and informed participation
• Privacy (control) vs. confidentiality (authorized access)
• Ownership and authorship responsibilities
• Data sharing and societal benefits
• Governance and custodianship for data management

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 4.pptx

document:
Ethical Issues
Ethics – moral principles guiding right and wrong actions.
Computing introduces new ethical challenges:
• Massive data scale
• Creation of digital entities without prior ethical frameworks
• Misuse of information and communication technologies

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 4.pptx

document:
Ethical Hacking
Ethical hackers test and secure systems under client direction.
They report vulnerabilities and provide mitigation strategies.
Growing demand due to rising malware and ransomware threats.
Key questions:
• What vulnerabilities exist?
• What can attackers access?
• How can issues be fixed?
Reference: https://www.eccouncil.org/ethical-hacking/

metadata.file_name: Module 1 - Application and Network Analysis - Part 4.pptx

Opportunities include research, hands-on learning, and service-learning hours.
Resources: routers, switches, racks, high-speed network, and drones.
Contact: cqu@fgcu.edu
